div.p:
I daresay you have often felt that pleasing calm which
some species of writing give the mind, a certain complacency
which renders it more - susceptible of agreeable Emotions; I have
this morning been reading the life of a great and good Man
-Dr.. Boerhaave - which had this delightful Effect upon mine, and
being desirous to prolong these Sensations by chusing some agreea-
-ble Employment, your kind letter immediately occurred [deletion]me[/deletion] to me,
Indeed, I thought it very kind! I hope by this time you have rec.d [deletion][/deletion][insertion]either[/insertion]
one of mine which will prove to you that I had not forgotten you
It seems as if both our last letters had been copied from each other
the ideas are so very similar, and yet we are at least a hundred
miles distant from one another! [deletion] Sympathy then [unclear][/unclear][/deletion]
[deletion][/deletion]! Did not your own occur to your mind when you
read mine? I dont know how it is but we seem to like one another
better now we are parted than ever we did when we were together -
Perhaps we must blame our tempers for this; will you forgive me for
saying our? I am willing to bear a double portion of the Blame myself
But I hope when (for I can't persuade myself to say if) ever we meet
again this obstacle will be removed on my side, I am sure it will on yours
& pray don't speak in such a doubting manner of the probability
of that meeting - I am not bound to Ireland for ever & ever for I dare-
-say my father will take a trip some fair day or other to surprize
2
his friends in England -
You say Miss Hartley intends to honor me with a letter, I believe
if you have read my last [deletion]letter[/deletion] you know how much I wish it! but least
you should think me proud or capricious I will explain my reasons
and if they are wrong pray set them right - In the sentimental phrase
there was never any great Sympathy between us - I thought her a
very clever Girl but her heart appeared to me the least desirable part
about her, (if I am unjust let me again beg you to tell me so for I am
sure I should be very sorry to be so) - I had no reason to suppose that
she had any partiality for me, and I doubt whether if she had been
asked the same question she would have given the same answer you
gave Miss Van; an answer which flattering as it was I thought too
kind even to forget - In short I never could depend much on friends
who lavished [insertion]such[/insertion] hyperbolical protestations of love as I have seen in
some of Miss H's letters - the superlatives dearest, Best most amiable
applied indiscrimonately on all her various Loves don't strike me
as expressions of real feeling but as words to fill up a sentence
or harmonize a period - the three or four lines in the postcript
of your kind letter made more impression on my mind [deletion]than[/deletion], writ-
-ten as they evidently were in haste, than a thousand labored Sen-
:timents or highflown Compliments - and why? because I
thought them natural, because they did not appear to be writ-
-ten to shew off fine writing but to express the genuine feelings
of the Heart - A pretty letter is a pretty thing, it may make [deletion]a[/deletion]
me admire the Writer; but I am afraid It would never in the least en-
-crease my love for the Woman. How should I estimate the real
sentiments of a friend if they are all exaggerated? I think I sh.d rather
feel inclined to disbelieve them all - I have been so cautious
3 of exaggerating with you that [deletion]I am[/deletion] perhaps you have thought me more
indifferent than I am, but I had infinitely rather you sh.d think so
than that you should an instant doubt whether what I say is senti-
-ment or truth - Once more if Miss Hartley is altered tell me so -
and for a Supplement to this Chapter see Mad.mede de Genlis Dangers du Monde - You have it
You desire me to read Julia de Roubigne if I should meet
with it, I won't promise you that I will, for though I am as fond of
novels as you can be I am afraid they act on the constitution of the
mind as Drams do on that of the body. - - But your recommendation
will induce me to read any other species of Books - Have you finish-
-ed Rollin's Ancient History yet and how do you like it? - I am reading
the History of the only Conqueror I ever liked - Peter justly stiled
the Great - I shall read the life of Charles the twelfth as soon as I
have finished it but I am afraid all Voltaire's Eloquence will
not prevent my wishing his hero to lose every Battle & fail in every
attack upon [insertion]his[/insertion] generous & moderate Adversary - I have finished
Moliere's & have began Marivaux's [insertion]Theatre[/insertion] Molieres entertained me
very much, the plots of all I have yet read of Marivaux I think too
much alike & too uninteresting; indeed that [deletion]I think[/deletion] is a fault
I have met with in most french plays - the waiting women & valets
are mere machinery to help the Author through his plot & to bring
their Masters & Mistresses in spite of fate together - You see I read
several Books on different subjects at a time, not at once, did you
ever try this method, I think you would find it succeed - change
of Employment [deletion][/deletion] refreshes without relaxing the mind -
If you won't think you are reading a review instead of a letter I should add
one Book more to this long Catalogue - I don't know whether you are fond of
such Subjects, but if you are I think you would be very much pleased with
Smith's Theory of moral Sentiments - It is neither abstruse pendantic
or prolix - the language is easy & elegant & an appearance of
Benevolence in the character of the man heightens the affect he has [insertion]on[/insertion] an
Author, indeed I dont know any Book which gave me so high an opi-
-nion of the private character of the writer as this, except Dr. Gregory's ad-
-vice to his Daughters which you may remember lending me at Mrs.. D's
& whether it was the time at which I read it, as I was then allowed to
read very little, or the instrinsic merit of the book I can't tell but it made
an impression upon me which I have never forgotten - how I have
done with Books; Are not you rejoiced to get out of the Study .... But
stop one minute & look at my fine Drawings - What strange things
are these? - You may well ask - They are meant to express lines in
some of the best english Authors, their names are written at the top of the
line on the Reverse; But pray don't look at it till you are tired of guess-
-ing for if they are well done they ought to tell themselves - We have
been very well entertained with this diversion for this week past
& wishing you to partake if possible in any little amusement we can
divide at such a distance. I drew two or three to send you - You
see the drawing is not meant to be attended to, they are rough Sketches
for fine drawing would not answer the purpose - [deletion]the other[/deletion] I hope
you w'ont imagine that I mean to send you the flowers for the
Beauty of the painting - I only send them [insertion]to[/insertion] try. an Experiment, as if they
are spoilt they can be no loss to either of us - Since they were done which
is two or three months ago, I hope I am improved. I have just finish-
-ed a flowerpot full of flowers which I wish very much to send over
but I am afraid describing it will [deletion][/deletion] spoil the colors
this is what I want to try upon the Inclosed - If it sh.d come with-
-out being rubbed to pieces & if you think the folds don't spoil it I will
send the other - To give you an idea of its size I will tell you the flowers
a Rose, a myrtle & jessamine, five sweet peas, a Geranium, a Carna-
tion, a Lark-spur & a lily of the Valey - it is done upon a large
sheet of paper - I shall not mind spoiling it if you have a mind to run the Risk
From September the 15th.. to Oct.r 28th.. have I delayed sending my letter
in hopes of hearing from you my dear Fanny - but I have no right to
complain I confess upon Recollection - to night however is post night
& I hope to hear from you, and (for I can't help flattering myself)
from Miss Burney -
Nov.r 2d.. - This instant have I rec.d your most entertaining letter
(I hate the word Epistle though it is a favorite of your's) and though I
think I seldom if ever was more anxious about anything in my
life, you contrived to make me forget my disappointment about
Miss Burney entirely - How much your hand, how much
your Style, how much you yourself you are improved!
it is actually twelve o'clock but I can't persuade myself
to go to bed without telling you so - I promise you your
Ha! ha! ha's were gloriously [unclear]reecchoed[/unclear], inwardly I mean
for I was in company & you know its monstrous unpolite
to be natural! But here am I come to my own Room to
enjoy myself in full Plenitude -
So Hartley's a great friend of your's well then I am sure she
must be altered & I shall be very glad to play treble basse with
you both -- You ask me, though [deletion][/deletion] in the handsomest
manner possible, what I erased in my last letter; you are very
good!; but I assure you if I wished to conceal it from you it was
merely for fear of exposing myself - I had hastily sketched
a plan of a play [insertion]in[/insertion] which with my father's Assistance - I afterwards
continued to discover such Egregious absurdities that I was
absolutely ashamed of having written it - That's all -
But I will now send you over a Scene or two & more of the
[insertion]new[/insertion] plan to morrow - - Yes and to morrow by the Blessing of
God you shall have Enough! perhaps you'll think too
much - for to night Adieu -
Past twelve o'clock a cloudy morning
now for it! - You flatter me very much by asking my opinion
about the Comet or rather Meteor - I assure you I am totally in-
-caple of forming any opinion, but I will tell you the facts & that
is a great step towards discovering the causes - Naturalists
and Philosophers too often err from that impatience of Genius
which soars into the lofty regions of Immagination regardless
of the plain & narrow but certain path of truth - there's a fine
sentence! and as many Epithets as Dr. Johnson himself could
cram into it - My father was returning home from Lord
Granard's who lives about nine Miles off, between ten & eleven or
nine & ten at night, in a phaeton with the head up - when just
over his horses head he perceived a sudden glowing light-
a Ball of fire [insertion]of[/insertion] about half the apparent Diameter of the
moon, glided with an even slow & uniform motion
[unclear]bys[/unclear] it disappeared at Intervals but reemerged in a few se-
-conds without any apparent change either in itself or its
direction - It had Rims of all the prismatic colors but with-
-out any gradation of Shade, it continued its course for about
fifteen seconds & disappeared totally and instantly without
any alteration in its [deletion][/deletion] [insertion]velocity[/insertion], or apparent[deletion]ly[/deletion] dimini[deletion][/deletion][insertion]tion[/insertion] in
5 zize previous to its total Dissolution or rather vanishment if
there be such a word - "John, said my father to the Servant who
attended him, when he [insertion]came[/insertion] home, how large do you think the Ball
of fire was we saw to night? - In troth and please your honor
I was so scared I did not mind [insertion]it[/insertion] much; but I think to the best
of my knowledge it seemed to be as big as a [insertion]coach[/insertion] House! John
was the coachman what a characteristical Allusion! [deletion]I think [/deletion]
[deletion][/deletion]
In the Drummer I remember to have met with a similar
humorous stroke- The house maid thinks the apparition
was like a Broom, the Coach man like a Coach House &
the Cook like a Spit; by the bye the Drummer contains more
humor of a certain style than many plays which are more
celebrated - Addison they say borrowed or rather translated
it from a french play - I forget who was the Author - You would
be infinitely diverted with the strokes of character & Irish
Bulls as they are called [deletion][/deletion] which I laugh at almost
every day & all day long - a laborer came with a com-
-plaint to my father & concluded with these words "& He
"bid me go to the Devil & I came straight to your Honor"
Lubin, in Marmontel's tales makes exactly the same Blun-
-der and I believe in exactly the same words - Authors don't
always exaggerate - I am very much obliged to you for the
favor you intend doing me in sending me Mr. Robinson's Verses
are they as pretty as his drawings? if they are they must be ele-
-gant indeed & the sister arts often go together - I wish Ms.
R. could take even the faintest Resemblance of you; I dare
-say you are very much altered, how I long to see you! -
I have myself attempted an Ode on Enthusiasm - I see you smile -
But I assure you its mighty fine & if my Muse will be good I'll
finish it to night and send it you - however I can't promise for
Muse' is [unclear]but[/unclear] a homo[insertion]u[/insertion]rsome, untoward Chitt & won't always come
when I call her; besides she has a strange Antipathy to light
and Motion, not that she loves the shades of some embowering
Wood but a good soft warm Bed & a moon shiny night when
[deletion][/deletion] "Not A breath disturbs the deep Serene."
So you see you are at the Mercy of the Moon & a Warming pan
The scenes which I have sent you are quite detached from
one another & are only meant to show you the Characters
of my Gods and Goddesses - I mean to christen the Babe it:
[insertion]-self[/insertion] Anticipation or the Countess - But I wish you would stand
Godmother & give it a better name for I do'nt like this -
If you dont criticize & boldly too I'll not send you another
line of it - But perhap that would be a reward instead of
a punishment --- Are the Gossips overdone?- or would they
Take on the Stage? - Now don't tell me that its all mighty
well and you can see no faults in it, because do you see if you
do I shall think you wo'nt[insertion]tell me of them[/insertion] not that you cant see them -
Now indulge me in talking to you of a Subject
which can be no ways interesting to you but which fills my
whole mind (except when it's empty) the present state of Politics
here - What should you think of a civil War? upon my word
there's danger - The people are in a [insertion]state of[/insertion] universal Fermentation
The Counties, Corps, Provinces, are all sending Delegates &
making what they call spirited Resolutions - A free
Parliamint! is the cry - & a free parliament they will have
or none at all - There is to be one of the greatest and [insertion]most[/insertion] Respectable
Meetings held on Monday Next (To decide on some plan to be support
-ed by the united Exertions of all the Volunteers of Ireland) that
ever was seen in this or perhaps in any other Country - My Fa-
-ther went up to Town this morning as a Delegate from this County
to speak at it - When he first came over to this Kingdom last
year he dispersed several hundred Copies of an address to the
People inciting them to attend to this great point preferably to
all others - His Address & Exertions had as compleat success
as he could have hoped; [deletion][/deletion] the heads of other
Corps cooperated in his views, & there seems to be no doubt
that a [deletion][/deletion] Reformation will take place in a very
short time - for it is to be done by a Coup de Main or not at all
To use a vulgar Expression. They must strike while the Iron
is hot, give the people time to cool & it's all over - They say
your Ministry in England mean to oppose it with[deletion][/deletion] all there
strength & the Catholics here hint that if they are not allowed
the right of voting they will join them - But I cant believe
it, The Mi[insertion]ni[/insertion]sters of England must be too well informed to think
the Volunteer Army nothing but a Name, or to venture to tri-
-fle with several 1000 Men in Arms with a Charlemont an Ogle
and a Flood at their head - besides the opposition are ready
to step into their places & help us whenever we call upon them -
I tell you what my dear Fanny, I am not too proud to be vain
and so let me praise my father, for [insertion]for[/insertion] the soul of me I can't help it -
This Speech to the Leinster Delegates was rec.d with the greatest
applause & the Newspapers [deletion][/deletion] say that
he had most graceful Action, pleasing pronunciation
9
possible Eloquence &c &c - Pray look some times into our Irish
papers & see what's doing here - for my family's Sake if not for
your Amusement & cast your Eye over a Map of Ireland now
& then, that you may'nt be frightened out of your Senses when
I come to talk of Drogheda, & Dungannon & Tipperary & Carrick
-fergus & a few other such names which may-hap will sound
a little uncouth or so, to a Musical Ear -- Now pray do'nt
be prouder than I am & let your vanity loose wherever you have [insertion]a mind[/insertion]
it shall be very safe with me I assure you & trust me we shall never
like one another a bit the worse for being sincere [deletion][/deletion]
[deletion][/deletion] - Moliere says the french are the only peo-
-ple who can laugh at their [insertion]own[/insertion] vanity - Not so neither, for I'll answer
for it I can laugh as heartily at mine as you can - There's for
you - So don't be proud or I'll be proud too & I'll always
write to you in full dress - - - - - - - -
Give my love to Penelope and tell her I shall always be very
glad for her to see my letters (if you please) & hope nay expect
she will add a line in your's whenever she is at home if it be
only to say "I'm alive ho!- Laugh her out of her fears and Ask
her as Mr. Amici used to ask us "Me croyez vous donc un ours?"
Pray how came you to stop just when you had raised my
Curiosity about Miss Ekins.? do you mean Louisa Ekins? I was
at school with her for a twelve-Month - "I thought her to use
Miss Burney's words (who you see still runs in my head, a pretty
but affected Young Lady"- I suppose she does not say much
more for me, but you know me my dear Fanny & I flatter myself
you will not suffer any one to usurp my place in your heart or judge
me without a hearing - Pray if I have tired you to death throw
all this into the fire & forget every thing in it except that I am my dear
girl with increasing friendship

Oh! about the sentence of which you so gravely ask me my
opinion, I think it neither like Dr. J.s language or like any
body else's - for it appears to me neither more or less than
compleatcomplete nonsense -
postscript.l: What is the strange affair in the newspaper about
Miss Patterson & Lady - I do no who?
postscript.p:
You ask me about my Eyes - they are bravobravis-
simo but "Oh my poor head"I have such perpetual
nervousheadaches | if I may use the word without
Affectation, that they sometimes absolutely in-
capacitate me for either pleasure or Business
& I assure you a good appetite is not at all
incompatible with all this - Indeed I
pity Mrs D's
"Taught by my own to pity other's Woe."
and seriously I hope riding will be of Ser- vice to her, but I am afraid she had recourse to
Exercise too late - Nervous habits last -
Present myrespectuful compliments to Lady Robinson
her Ladyship is very obliging to furnish me with franks -
You will think me very Extravagant in using two at a
Time, indeed I believe if I had I should fill them
all -

I hope M r Robinson's complaint in his Eyes is entirely
removed - you see I am interested in every thing which concerns
your family so pray talk to me about them, though I have not
the honor of their Acquaintance. - Pray what use have you
made of your Box for cards 0 I wish I had, had one of them they
would be the nicest things in the World to keep your letters in after
I had demolished the Divisions - But I will get one made -
So many things come into my head when I think I have done
with you that my postscripts are almost as long as my letters

Besides a postscript is a most convenient for ques-
tions & odd thoughts - pell mell -
To Miss Burlton's gone or going - You know she was always very fond of
singing "When I am a Widow Oh then! Oh then! - ! Was there prophetic in the
Song. -
